THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court

  
    
      
        D'Angelo Stradford, Respondent
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        State of South Carolina, Petitioner
      
    
  


Appeal From Kershaw County
Wyatt T. Saunders, Plea Judge
Â Alison Renee Lee, PCR Judge

Memorandum Opinion No. 2005-MO-006
Submitted January 20, 2005 â€“ Filed February 7, 2005

REVERSED


  
    
      
        Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley Elliott, Assistant Attorney General Christopher L. Newton, all of the Office of the Attorney General, of Columbia, for Petitioner.
        Assistant Appellate Defender Eleanor Duffy Cleary, Office of Appellate Defense, of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  


PER CURIAM:Â  Reversed pursuant to Rule 220(b)(1), SCACR, and the following authorities: Â Whitehead v. State, 352 S.C. 215, 574 S.E.2d 200 (2002)(holding State waived right to raise defense of laches to defendant's second PCR application asserting Austin claim); and Gallman v. State, 307 S.C. 273, 414 S.E.2d 780, 782 (1992)(holding a PCR judge's findings will not be upheld if such findings are not supported by probative evidence). 

REVERSED.
TOAL, C.J., MOORE, WALLER, BURNETT and PLEICONES, JJ., concur.

  PER CURIAM:Â  Petitioner seeks a writ of certiorari from the denial of his application for post-conviction relief
  (PCR).
  The petition is denied on petitionerâ€™s Question II.Â  Because there is sufficient evidence to support the PCR judgeâ€™s finding that petitioner did not knowingly and intelligently waive his right to a direct appeal, we grant certiorari on petitionerâ€™s Question I and proceed with a review of the direct appeal issues pursuant to Davis v. State, 288 S.C. 290, 342 S.E.2d 60 (1986).
  The direct appeal issues are dismissed under Rule 220(b)(1), SCACR, after review pursuant to Anders v. California, 386 U.S. 738 (1967).Â  Counselâ€™s motion to be relieved is granted.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT SHOULD NOT BE 
  CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED BY RULE 
  239(d)(2), SCACR.
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
The State,       
Petitioner,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Anthony W. Nellis, Jr.,       
Respondent.
      
    
  


ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI TO THE COURT
OF APPEALS

Appeal From Dorchester County
Jackson V. Gregory, Circuit Court Judge

Memorandum Opinion No. 2005-MO-008
Heard November 3, 2004 â€“ Filed February 
  28, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John 
  W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Charles H. Richardson, and Senior 
  Assistant Attorney General Harold M. Coombs, Jr., all of Columbia; and Walter 
  M. Bailey, Jr., of Summerville, for Petitioner.
Kelly Knight Byrd, Jennifer L. Queen, and Mark Alan Leiendecker, all of Summerville, 
  for Respondent.
      
    
  


JUSTICE PLEICONES:Â  We granted certiorari to review a decision of the 
  Court of Appeals reversing respondentâ€™s conviction and remanding the matter 
  for a new trial.Â  State v. Nellis, Op. No. 2003-UP-459 (S.C. Ct. App. 
  filed July 8, 2003).Â  We affirm.
The Court of Appeals found error and prejudice in the admission of 
  alleged prior bad acts committed upon the victim by respondent.Â  We agree.

Evidence of other crimes must be put to a rather severe 
  test before admission.Â  The acid test of admissibility is the logical relevancy 
  of the other crimes.Â  The trial judge must clearly perceive the connection between 
  the other crimes and the crimes charged.Â  [Citation omitted].Â  Further, other 
  crimes which are not the subject of conviction must be proven by clear and convincing 
  evidence.Â  [Citation omitted].

 State v. Cutro, 332 S.C. 
  100, 103, 504 S.E.2d 324, 325 (1998).Â  
The victimâ€™s testimony was vague and inconsistent.Â  Whether there was logical 
  relevancy between the crime charged and the other alleged assaults is a close 
  question: whether there was clear and convincing evidence of these other incidents 
  is not.Â  The trial judge erred in admitting the prior bad acts evidence.Â  State 
  v. Cutro, supra.Â  The decision of the Court of Appeals is
AFFIRMED.
MOORE, WALLER, BURNETT, JJ., concur.Â  TOAL, 
  C.J., dissenting in a separate opinion.


Chief Justice Toal:Â  I respectfully dissent.Â  In my view, 
  the prior bad acts committed upon the victim by Respondent are admissible.Â Â Â  
  Therefore, I would reverse the decision of the court of appeals and uphold Respondentâ€™s 
  conviction.
The majority misconstrues the law to the extent that it holds 
  the prior bad acts by Respondent are not relevant.Â  In my opinion, the prior 
  bad acts are relevant and should be admitted.Â  I find the reasoning set forth 
  in State v. Weaverling to be persuasive.Â  337 S.C. 460, 468, 523 S.E.2d 
  787, 791 (Ct. App. 1999).Â  When a criminal defendantâ€™s prior bad acts are directed 
  toward the same victim and are very similar in nature, those acts are admissible 
  as a common scheme or plan.Â  State v. Weaverling, 337 S.C. at 468, 523 
  S.E.2d at 791.Â  In Weaverling, the defendant repeatedly raped the same 
  child.Â  Id. at 465, 523 S.E.2d at 789.Â  The court of appeals held the 
  defendantâ€™s prior acts were admissible even though the acts were not charged.Â  
  Id. at 468, 523 S.E.2d at 791.Â  The court reasoned that â€œ[w]here the 
  evidence is of such a close similarity to the charged offense that the previous 
  act enhances the probative value of the evidence so as to overrule the prejudicial 
  effect, it is admissible.â€ Id.Â  (citing State v. Raffaldt, 318 
  S.C. 110, 456 S.E.2d 390 (1995)).Â  Moreover, the admission of evidence in a 
  criminal prosecution is within the discretion of the trial court, and its ruling 
  will not be disturbed on appeal unless an abuse of discretion is shown.Â  State 
  v. Wright, 322 S.C. 253, 255, 471 S.E.2d 700, 701 (1996).
In the present case, evidence was presented that the same 
  victim was attacked on several occasions.Â  However, none of the prior incidents 
  were reported or charged.Â  In my opinion, these prior acts should be admitted 
  to show a common plan or scheme and any prejudice from the admission of the 
  evidence would be outweighed by its probative value.Â  
Further, in my opinion, the victimâ€™s testimony was not vague 
  and inconsistent.Â  The victim testified that Respondent raped her on several 
  occasions, in the same manner.Â  The victim testified further that on all prior 
  occasions and the incident that led to charges, Respondent attacked the victim 
  at the home.Â  Accordingly, it is my opinion that prior bad acts were shown by 
  clear and convincing evidence.
Therefore, in my opinion, the Respondentâ€™s prior bad acts 
  were properly admitted by the trial court.Â  Accordingly, I would affirm the 
  ruling of the trial judge and uphold Respondentâ€™s conviction.

THIS OPINION HAS NO PRECEDENTIAL VALUE.Â  IT 
  SHOULD NOT BE CITED OR RELIED ON AS PRECEDENT IN ANY PROCEEDING EXCEPT AS PROVIDED 
  BY RULE 239(d)(2), SCACR. 
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
Theresa Kaiser,       
Respondent,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
John Christopher Kaiser,       
Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Beaufort County
Robert S. Armstrong, Family Court Judge

Memorandum Opinion No. 2005-MO-009
Heard January 6, 2005 â€“ Filed February 
  28, 2005

REVERSED AND REMANDED


  
    
      
H. Fred Kuhn, Jr., of Moss, Kuhn & Fleming, PA, and Peter L. Fuge, both 
  of Beaufort, for Appellant.
William Randall Phipps, of Phipps & Geis, PA, of Hilton Head Island, for 
  Respondent.
      
    
  


 JUSTICE WALLER:Â  This is a domestic case involving the custody 
  of a minor child.Â  The family court judge awarded custody of the child to the 
  mother and the father appeals.Â  We reverse and remand.
FACTS
Theresa (â€œMotherâ€) and John Kaiser (â€œFatherâ€) were married 
  August 14, 1998. [1]  The coupleâ€™s only child, Collin 
  Kaiser (â€œChildâ€), was born September 9, 1999.Â  Father owns a pest control business 
  on Hilton Head Island, and Mother did not work during the marriage after she 
  became pregnant with Child.Â  
The parties separated in May 2001 and on September 7, 2001, 
  the family court issued a Pendente Lite Order granting Wife $3,000 per month 
  alimony, possession of the marital home, and custody of Child.Â  In December 
  2001, Father moved to terminate the alimony on the ground that Mother had engaged 
  in adulterous conduct with two men after the commencement of this divorce action.Â Â  
  Mother admitted she had a sexual relationship with one of the men and alleged 
  she has a continuing platonic relationship with the other.Â  
On January 17, 2002, because of the admitted adultery, the 
  family court terminated Motherâ€™s alimony and ordered reimbursement of the previously 
  paid alimony.Â  The family court entered its final order on August 20, 2002, 
  and awarded Mother custody of Child. Father appeals. 
ISSUE

Did the family court err in granting custody of Child to 
  Mother?

DISCUSSION 
Father contends the family court erred in granting Mother 
  custody of Child.Â  We agree.Â  
Where a family court order is appealed, this Court has jurisdiction 
  to find facts based on its own view of the preponderance of the evidence. Patel 
  v. Patel, 359 S.C. 515,Â  522, 599 S.E.2d 114, 118Â  (2004).Â  The paramount 
  and controlling factor in every custody dispute is the best interest of the 
  child.Â  Hooper v. Rockwell, 334 S.C. 281, 513 S.E.2d 358 (1999).Â  In 
  determining the best interest of the child in a custody dispute, the family 
  court should consider several factors, including: who has been the primary caretaker; 
  the conduct, attributes, and fitness of the parents; the opinions of third parties 
  (including the guardian, expert witnesses, and the children); and the age, health, 
  and sex of the children.Â  Patel, 347 S.C. at 285, 555 S.E.2d at 388. 

Father contends the family court erred in awarding Mother 
  custody of Child.Â  Father summarizes his reasons Mother should not have been 
  awarded custody:Â  â€œMother 1)Â  has a history of substance abuse, 2) is an alcoholic, 
  3) is sexually promiscuous, 3) (sic) suffers from post-traumatic stress disorder, 
  4) has attempted suicide and threatened to commit suicide, 5) is a mother whose 
  selfish behavior has exposed her son to various men of questionable characters, 
  6) lied to the court, 7) has no respect for the Courtâ€™s Orders, and 8)Â  moreover, 
  this is a mother who has no respect for herself or her son.â€  
  [2] Â  
Without a doubt, Mother has had some emotional and mental 
  problems. [3] Â  Prior to the partiesâ€™ 
  marriage, Mother attempted suicide and was hospitalized for one night at the 
  State Mental Hospital.Â  She was sexually abused as a child by her babysitters, 
  and her psychologist, Dr. Marion Oâ€™Neill, has diagnosed her with post-traumatic 
  stress disorder (PTSD) caused by this abuse.Â  She also has been diagnosed with 
  a histrionics type personality. [4] Â  She is now a recovering alcoholic and regularly 
  attends AA.Â  
Both the Guardian ad Litem (GAL) and the court-appointed 
  psychologist, Dr. David Brandt, recommended that Father be awarded custody. 
   [5]  The GAL was concerned about Motherâ€™s relationships 
  with men and that if Mother was given custody she would â€œlikely limit contact 
  with [Father] rather than seeking to expand such contactâ€ and thus he recommended 
  Father be granted custody.Â  The GAL noted that Mother had a post-separation 
  sexual affair with Bruce Pitkin, the investigator working on this case.Â  Mother 
  admitted to this relationship.Â  Additionally, there were allegations that Mother 
  had a sexual relationship with Eddie Bergeron, whom she met at an AA meeting.Â  
  Bergeron and Mother deny their relationship has been sexual.Â  However, as the 
  GAL noted Mother and Bergeron have taken overnight trips and spent the night 
  together under circumstances â€œstrongly suggesting an ongoing and romantic and 
  sexual relationship.â€Â  Further, Bergeron acknowledges having romantic feelings 
  for Mother. Mother acknowledges that both men have been in the Childâ€™s presence. 

Dr. Brandt found the custody issue a close call, but he 
  eventually recommended Father be given custody because he believed Father would 
  be more likely to share Child with Mother.Â  Additionally, he was very concerned 
  with Motherâ€™s exposure of Child to her paramours.Â  Dr. Brandt was concerned 
  about Childâ€™s potential sense of loss when Mother stopped seeing the men.Â  
The family court rejected the GAL's and Dr. Brandtâ€™s recommendations.Â  
  We recognize that rather than merely adopting the recommendation of the GAL 
  or psychologist, the court, by its own review of all the evidence, should consider 
  the character, fitness, attitude, and inclinations on the part of each parent 
  as they impact the child as well as all psychological, physical, environmental, 
  spiritual, educational, medical, family, emotional and recreational aspects 
  of the child's life. See Woodall v. Woodall, 322 S.C. 7, 11, 471 
  S.E.2d 154, 157 (1996). The role of the GAL and psychologist in making custody 
  recommendations is to aid, not direct, the court.Â  Ultimately, the custody decision 
  lies with the trial judge. See Shainwald v. Shainwald, 302 S.C. 
  453, 395 S.E.2d 441 (Ct.App.1990) (GAL does not usurp judge's function). 
Â Here, the family court judge specifically stated that he 
  placed the greatest of weight upon Mother being the primary caretaker of the 
  child from birth. Although the family court judge recited that he had â€œconsidered 
  the character, fitness, attitudes and inclinations on the part of each parent 
  as they impact the childâ€ and reviewed the expert witness reports, he does not 
  explain why he rejects the opinions of the GAL and psychologist.Â  It is apparent 
  the family court judge placed all the weight on who was the primary caretaker.Â  
  The family court judge found Wifeâ€™s conduct with her paramour to be â€œinappropriate 
  and not in the best interests of the child.â€ Yet, he did not address this or 
  consider Motherâ€™s instability and continuing inappropriate behavior when he 
  awarded custody of Child.
We have reviewed the record and determine that it is in 
  the best interest of the Child for custody to be given to Father. The custody 
  decision here essentially turned on the single factor of Mother having been 
  the primary caretaker of the Child to the exclusion of the rest of the evidence 
  in the record.Â  Mother has demonstrated her continuing instability and inappropriate 
  behavior through her relationships with various men and the impact on the Child 
  cannot be overlooked.Â  We agree with the GAL and Dr. Brandt that Father should 
  be given custody of Child.Â  Accordingly, we reverse and remand for the family 
  court to award custody to Father and establish visitation for Mother.
REVERSED AND REMANDED.
TOAL, C.J., MOORE, BURNETT and PLEICONES, JJ., concur.

 
   [1] Father has two children from his first marriage 
    who live with their mother.Â  

 
   [2]  Mother repeatedly states in her brief that several 
    issues are not properly before the Court.Â  Specifically, she alleges that 
    Father has failed to set forth these issues in his statement of the issue 
    on appeal pursuant to Rule 208 (b)(1), SCACR.Â  We disagree.Â  Father alleges 
    the family court abused its discretion for numerous reasons which are clearly 
    encompassed by the broader issue on appeal of whether the family court erred 
    in awarding Mother custody. See Henson v. Inatâ€™l Paper Co., 
    358 S.C. 133, 142, 594 S.E.2d 499, 503 (Ct. App. 2004) (distinguishing case 
    where appellant challenged two separate rulings made by trial court).Â  

 
   [3]  We recognize Father also has engaged in some questionable 
    behavior.Â  However, most of this behavior was prior to the birth of Child.

 
   [4] A histrionic personality is characterized by inappropriate 
    sexual behavior and the need to be the center of attention.Â  

 
   [5] The GAL issued two reports and in both he recommended 
    that Father be given custody of Child.
